image.altText: A man with a backwards cap holding a football.

items.synopsis: Daniel Hayes was forging a path to a dream career in the AFL 17 years ago — but after leaving the Demons without playing a game, the small forward was left grappling with feelings few understood.

title.children: When Daniel Hayes disappeared from the AFL, he didn't share his pain — now he is suing his junior coach

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff sits in parliament and listens while holding a finger to support his cheek.

items.synopsis: Concerns over a contentious $715 million stadium and the government's priorities have pushed two Tasmanian MPs to quit the Liberal Party and sit as independents, ending Premier Jeremy Rockliff's majority.

title.children: Anger over Hobart AFL stadium sinks Tasmania's government into minority as MPs quit party

image.altText: Peter Dutton Budget reply

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says JobSeeker recipients should be allowed to work more hours without it eating into their payments, as he responds to the federal budget.

title.children: Dutton says JobSeeker recipients should be allowed to work more instead of having payments increased

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: Despite increased rental assistance measures in Tuesday's budget, calls to cap rents are growing louder, with economists saying that step has been successful overseas, however, analysts warn it may make the housing crisis worse.

title.children: 'We need intervention': Renters say price caps are needed to help keep a roof over their heads

image.altText: A man in a business shirt and tie looks seriously off the camera.

items.synopsis: The report contains highly critical reviews of NT Police processes and concerns raised by prosecutors about the expert witnesses called in the murder case against former police officer Zachary Rolfe.

title.children: Suppression order lifted over controversial police report into death of Kumanjayi Walker

image.altText: A composite image of two photos of the faces of Moira Deeming and John Pesutto.

items.synopsis: Victorian Liberal MPs are meeting in Melbourne to decide whether to expel controversial MP Moira Deeming from their ranks, a day after she flagged a possible defamation lawsuit against leader John Pesutto. Follow live.

title.children: Victorian Liberals in meeting to decide fate of exiled MP Moira Deeming

image.altText: Justin Tkatchenko with PNG's governor general Sir Bob Bofeng Dadae in formal suits.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister James Marape asks the people of Papua New Guinea to "forgive" the country's foreign minister after his apology for his "primitive animals" comments.

title.children: 'Unsavoury use of words': PNG's PM says he was offended by foreign minister's 'primitive animals' comment

image.altText: A proposed stadium design at Hobart's Macquarie Point, bordering the Hobart Cenotaph.

items.synopsis: Just yesterday, the Tasmanian government was sailing along relatively smoothly as the only remaining Liberal government in the country, but two bombshell resignations have changed all that, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: The Tasmanian premier's $715 million stadium is costing him more than money

image.altText: A serious-looking woman standing on the bank of a creek behind her and staring up into the sun.

items.synopsis: Larrakia traditional owners raised concerns with federal and territory ministers about the potential impact of a major industrial hub planned for Darwin before $1.5 billion of Commonwealth funding was confirmed.

title.children: FOI documents show ministers were told of risks to cultural sites at industrial hub near Darwin

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump claps his hand together at rally in Manchester, New Hampshire.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump signals he will appeal against a jury's decision to find him liable for sexual abuse and defamation, a day after joking about the case during a controversial CNN broadcast.

title.children: Trump lodges appeal against sexual abuse finding as CNN grapples with town hall fallout

image.altText: Dutton wearing glasses speaks on the floor of parliament house.

items.synopsis: Peter Dutton failed to sketch a big picture to look like an alternative prime minister in his Thursday night budget reply, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Peter Dutton's concern for the 'working poor' not enough to demonstrate big-picture vision in budget reply

image.altText: A close up photo of Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh under an umbrella. She is smiling.

items.synopsis: A woman in her 80s remains in critical condition after being hit by a police motorcycle that was escorting Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh.

title.children: Police investigation launched after Duchess of Edinburgh's motorcycle escort hits elderly woman

image.altText: Profile shot of Ms R Rubuntja

items.synopsis: The Albanese government allocated $194 million to prevent domestic violence against First Nations women in Tuesday's budget. With some of the highest rates of domestic violence in the world, is it enough?

title.children: 'Three friends of mine have been killed by their partners': Are we on track to end violence against women?

image.altText: Craig Kelly in a yellow hat.

items.synopsis: United Australia Party national director Craig Kelly says the TGA 'surrendered" on antiparasitic drug ivermectin with its decision to allow off-label prescription once again. But what actually happened?

title.children: Former Liberal MP Craig Kelly claims the TGA has 'surrendered' on ivermectin. Is that correct?

image.altText: Voyager

items.synopsis: Australia will compete in the 2023 Eurovision grand final, with synth-metal band Voyager voted in after a glittering performance in the second semifinal.

title.children: Australia's Voyager is through to the Eurovision 2023 grand final

image.altText: Man wearing white Islamic cap with long brown beard sits in study with books behind and window with laced curtains behind

items.synopsis: A convicted terrorist is being kept in prison using orders that have been condemned in a Home Affairs inquiry. The department kept that report's findings secret — until now.

title.children: Home Affairs releases secret report trashing orders keeping terrorist behind bars

image.altText: Irina Tsybaneva stands in a courtroom in St. Petersburg, Russia.

items.synopsis: A Russian court gives a two-year suspended sentence to a St Petersburg woman who left a note on the grave of President Vladimir Putin's parents on the eve of his birthday that said they had "raised a freak and a killer".

title.children: Russian woman who left note on grave of Putin's parents calling him a 'freak' convicted

image.altText: Lesley Trotter in khaki hiking gear sitting on a rock with other walkers.

items.synopsis: Police believe the 78-year-old was killed the day she was reported missing — her body put in a wheelie bin near her home in Toowong, which was then collected by a rubbish truck.

title.children: Dumped in a bin outside her house six weeks ago, Lesley Trotter's disappearance remains a mystery

image.altText: Crash investigators inspect an off-road vehicle that has been loaded onto a truck.

items.synopsis: The national motorsport peak body has told a court it failed to do enough to keep people safe in the years leading up to a spectator's death at the Finke Desert Race in 2021.

title.children: Scathing safety report not acted on by organisers prior to fatal Finke Desert Race, inquest hears

image.altText: A handsome young man poses in a black and white photo with his hand on his chin

items.synopsis: Pita Limjaroenrat is a charismatic young businessman-turned-politician whose party has been climbing the polls. Here's how Move Forward is making is mark on mainstream Thai politics.

title.children: The young Harvard grad, the heiress and the coup leader: Inside Thailand's crucial race for PM

image.altText: Twitter logo and a photo of Elon Musk are displayed through magnifier in an illustration.

items.synopsis: Elon Musk says he has found a woman to replace him as chief executive officer of Twitter and its newly named parent company, X Corp.

title.children: Elon Musk says he has hired a woman to replace him as Twitter chief executive, but won't say who

image.altText: People are seen protesting in Washington Square Park in New York. A sign says "being houseless is not a crime".

items.synopsis: Manhattan prosecutors have said that they will bring criminal charges against a man who used a fatal chokehold on an unruly passenger aboard a New York City subway train.

title.children: Man who fatally choked New York City subway rider will face manslaughter charge, prosecutors say

image.altText: a woman holding onto an empty cardboard box outside a food charity

items.synopsis: Food charities are struggling to keep their pantries stocked with more hungry mouths to feed than ever before, but there was no joy in this week's federal budget.

title.children: Glenda gets all her family's meals from a food bank, but no budget relief means many will miss out

image.altText: Aerial footage of floodwater near Karumba

items.synopsis: Leaders in one of the country's most disadvantaged communities fear their towns will die if bridges are not raised before the next wet season.

title.children: Fears town 'won't survive' another disaster as pleas to PM for urgent funding fall flat

image.altText: A teenage girl smiles while lying in a hospital bed, as her mother holds the girl's hand to her cheek in support.

items.synopsis: Australian gymnast Ava Costa was on a possible track for the Olympics, but now faces a long recovery after a spinal injury from a training fall — prompting gymnastic greats to send their support.

title.children: Messages of love lift the spirits of injured Australian gymnastics star Ava Costa

image.altText: Imran Khan court

items.synopsis: Pakistan's Supreme Court orders the release of former prime minister Imran Khan, after his arrest sparked countrywide violence.

title.children: Pakistan's top court orders release of Imran Khan, who calls his arrest a 'kidnapping'

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Falls across most of the resources sector and a big drop for QBE on its latest earnings update are weighing the ASX down in morning trade. Stay across the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX weighed down by QBE earnings update, mining sell-off

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As indicated by the futures market, it's a pretty flat start to trade on the ASX. The ASX 200 was up 1 point at 7,253 around 10:15am AEST — that's point, not per cent — and the All Ords was down 2 points at 7,448. Most companies in the top 200 were doing well, with 131 in the black and only 65 in the red. But the mining sector, notably the big iron ore miners, were among those losing ground, weighing on the index as a whole. BHP (-1.7%), Rio Tinto (-1.4%) and Fortescue (-1.6%) were all down after spot iron ore prices dropped below $US100 a tonne, continuing recent trends on signs of Chinese economic weakness. QBE was another big company dragging on the market — investors clearly not impressed with its first quarter performance update, despite 11% growth in gross written premium. The company did warn about the cost of a number of natural disasters, which is already creeping towards its first half catastrophe allowance with a couple of months yet to go. QBE shares were down 5.1 per cent to $14.39. Healthcare, education and consumer cyclicals were today's leading sectors, with energy joining mining as the laggards. The big four banks were up between 0.2 and 1 per cent, with Westpac leading. Five biggest gains on ASX 200: News Corp: +4.1% to $25.81 GrainCorp: +2.6% to $8.015 Sayona Mining: +2.4% to $0.215 Imugene: +2.1% to $0.1225 Polynovo: +1.6% to $1.4125 Five biggest losses on ASX 200: Sandfire Resources: -5.2% to $6.16 QBE Insurance: -4.8% to $14.43 Champion Iron: -3.7% to $6.20 Regis Resources: -3.7% to $2.07 Paladin Energy: -3.7% to $0.66
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Miners, QBE weigh on ASX in early trade

around 10:15am AEST — that's point, not per cent — and the

Most companies in the top 200 were doing well, with 131 in the black and only 65 in the red.

were all down after spot iron ore prices dropped below $US100 a tonne, continuing recent trends on signs of Chinese economic weakness.

was another big company dragging on the market — investors clearly not impressed with its

, despite 11% growth in gross written premium.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) has taken action against three telcos for allowing the misuse, or potential misuse, of sender IDs. "ACMA investigations found Sinch Australia Pty Ltd (Sinch), Infobip Information Technology Pty Ltd (Infobip) and Phone Card Selector Pty Ltd (Phone Card) allowed SMS to be sent using text-based sender IDs without sufficient checks to ensure they were being used legitimately. "The ACMA found Infobip allowed 103,146 non-compliant SMS to be sent, which included scams impersonating well known Australian road toll companies. Sinch allowed 14,291 non-complaint SMS, which included Medicare and Australia Post impersonation scams. "Phone Card was also found to have inadequate systems in place to comply with the rules, however there is no evidence that scammers exploited the opportunities it created. "Text-based sender IDs can be used by scammers to pose as legitimate organisations such as government agencies, banks and road toll companies. Under the Reducing Scam Calls and Scam SMS Code, Australian telcos must obtain evidence from customers that they have a legitimate reason to use text-based sender IDs (such as business names) in SMS." Despite the tough talk, the penalties for the breaches are … nothing. "The ACMA has given Sinch and Infobip formal directions to comply with the obligations, the strongest enforcement action available for code breaches. Phone Card has been given a formal warning. "Combating SMS and identity theft phone scams is an ACMA compliance priority and telcos may face penalties of up to $250,000 for breaching ACMA directions to comply with the code."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telcos pinged over fake sender ID scam texts

children.content: The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) has taken action against three telcos for allowing the misuse, or potential misuse, of sender IDs.

"ACMA investigations found Sinch Australia Pty Ltd (Sinch), Infobip Information Technology Pty Ltd (Infobip) and Phone Card Selector Pty Ltd (Phone Card) allowed SMS to be sent using text-based sender IDs without sufficient checks to ensure they were being used legitimately.

"The ACMA found Infobip allowed 103,146 non-compliant SMS to be sent, which included scams impersonating well known Australian road toll companies. Sinch allowed 14,291 non-complaint SMS, which included Medicare and Australia Post impersonation scams.
"Phone Card was also found to have inadequate systems in place to comply with the rules, however there is no evidence that scammers exploited the opportunities it created.

"Text-based sender IDs can be used by scammers to pose as legitimate organisations such as government agencies, banks and road toll companies. Under the Reducing Scam Calls and Scam SMS Code, Australian telcos must obtain evidence from customers that they have a legitimate reason to use text-based sender IDs (such as business names) in SMS."
Despite the tough talk, the penalties for the breaches are … nothing.
"The ACMA has given Sinch and Infobip formal directions to comply with the obligations, the strongest enforcement action available for code breaches. Phone Card has been given a formal warning.
"Combating SMS and identity theft phone scams is an ACMA compliance priority and telcos may face penalties of up to $250,000 for breaching ACMA directions to comply with the code."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's been huge debate on this topic since Tuesday night's Commonwealth budget. A lot of economists, such as Steven Hamilton and Chris Richardson, argue measures to relieve the cost of living such as power bill subsidies will leave households with more money to spend and thus be inflationary, at least to some degree. But the Commonwealth Bank's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird, who was recently in the minority of market economists who successfully forecast the RBA's May rate hike, believes the budget may even help bring down inflation, as the Treasurer has claimed. "The Government's Energy Price Relief Plan is expected to subtract 0.75ppts [percentage points] from headline inflation in 2023/24. Medicare bulk billing incentives along with childcare subsidies will also put downward pressure directly on measured inflation. "It can be argued that these packages free up some consumer cash flow to spend on other goods and services. And therefore the second round impacts of the package are inflationary. But we don't subscribe to that view. "Inflation expectations are a driver of inflation over the medium term. And inflation expectation can be heavily influenced by actual inflation. Lowering measured inflation in the short run at a time when there remains lingering concerns around inflation psychology makes a lot of sense. It is both smart politics and smart economics. "Many wage agreements and price outcomes are set with the level of actual inflation in mind. If measured inflation recedes more quickly it can dampen down the consumer and business expectation of entrenching price rises – a welcome outcome." Westpac's chief economist Bill Evans has a slightly different view, but still thinks the budget will, at most, be a "second order" consideration for the RBA and unlikely to affect interest rates this year. "Our analysis points to the Budget being more expansionary than we saw in any of budgets the ten years before the pandemic," he wrote. "The Budget is still unlikely to be a core factor for the rate decision in August, but may delay the timing of the first rate cut in 2024." My colleague Kate Ainsworth had a comprehensive article earlier this week featuring both sides of the debate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the budget add to inflation? No says CBA

featuredLink.title: Budget heightens risk for the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates 'at least once' in coming months

Commonwealth Bank's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird
, who was recently in the minority of market economists who successfully forecast the RBA's May rate hike, believes the budget may even help bring down inflation, as the Treasurer has claimed.

props.alt: CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird

children.content: CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird
(ABC News: John Gunn)

"The Government's Energy Price Relief Plan is expected to subtract 0.75ppts [percentage points] from headline inflation in 2023/24. Medicare bulk billing incentives along with childcare subsidies will also put downward pressure directly on measured inflation.

"It can be argued that these packages free up some consumer cash flow to spend on other goods and services. And therefore the second round impacts of the package are inflationary. But we don't subscribe to that view.
"Inflation expectations are a driver of inflation over the medium term. And inflation expectation can be heavily influenced by actual inflation.
Lowering measured inflation in the short run at a time when there remains lingering concerns around inflation psychology makes a lot of sense. It is both smart politics and smart economics.

"Many wage agreements and price outcomes are set with the level of actual inflation in mind. If measured inflation recedes more quickly it can dampen down the consumer and business expectation of entrenching price rises – a welcome outcome."

Westpac's chief economist Bill Evans has a slightly different view, but still thinks the budget will, at most, be a "second order" consideration for the RBA and unlikely to affect interest rates this year.
"Our analysis points to the Budget being more expansionary than we saw in any of budgets the ten years before the pandemic," he wrote.
"The Budget is still unlikely to be a core factor for the rate decision in August, but may delay the timing of the first rate cut in 2024."
My colleague
Kate Ainsworth
had a comprehensive article earlier this week featuring both sides of the debate.

image.altText: A woman holds a medical syringe and a small bottle labelled "Coronavirus COVID-19 vaccine"

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.

title.children: All the latest COVID-19 case numbers from around Australia — plus the news you may have missed

image.altText: James McConville and Simon Stuart stand in military dress. Both are facing to the left, with the US General saluting.

items.synopsis: Australia's recent army overhaul will see a greater focus on missiles, but a senior American military general says cutting back on ground vehicles may be a mistake.

title.children: Tanks crucial to 'winning', US Army general says after Australia cuts back spending on fighting vehicles

image.altText: A truck sits in a field as a soldier aims a shoulder-mounted rocket laucher, while another looks through binoculars.

items.synopsis: Britain has become the first country to start supplying long-range cruise missiles to Ukraine — a move that will allow Kyiv's forces to hit Russian troops and supply dumps deep behind the front lines.

title.children: Britain to supply Ukraine with long-range cruise missiles

image.altText: Victoria Azarenka crouches to talk to Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula at the Madrid Open.

items.synopsis: The chief executive of the Madrid Open apologises after the women's doubles finalists were not allowed to address fans after their match and says it will never happen again, but the tournament is under fire for other issues regarding inequality.

title.children: Madrid Open apologises for not letting women's doubles finalists speak to crowd, other issues unaddressed

image.altText: Actor Michael J. Fox, a man with short dark hair with grey patches, cups his chin in his hands, looking thoughtful.

items.synopsis: A candid new documentary is a fitting tribute to a performer who refuses to meet life's curve balls with anything less than his signature good humour.

title.children: 'The cosmic price I had to pay for my success': Michael J. Fox opens up in new doco

image.altText: Gerald Friessbourg, a middle-aged man, sits in a recliner chair.

items.synopsis: Appropriate housing is a "fundamental human right". But it's far from guaranteed for people with a disability in public housing, writes Isabel Dayman.

title.children: Gerald's public housing property has him living in filth and constant pain. And he's not alone.

image.altText: A big black spider in a jar.

items.synopsis: An influx of donations to Sydney's anti-venom program suggests the native arachnids are unusually active for this time of year, but researchers urge caution — and not for the reason you may think.

title.children: Funnel-web spiders on the crawl in Sydney a boost to anti-venom stocks

image.altText: Ben Hunt gives a thumbs up while a child rides on his shoulders after State of Origin III.

items.synopsis: Ben Hunt has endured plenty of trials and tribulations through his long NRL career. Now preparing for his 300th first-grade match, the Queensland Origin star shows no sign of slowing down, writes Nick Campton.

title.children: About to play his 300th NRL game, Ben Hunt's never-say-die attitude remains
